dataset.title: Lichen resurvey with heavy metal analysis in Maricopa County, central Arizona, period 1998

creator.organizationName: School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University
School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University
Global Institute of Sustainability, Arizona State University
School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University

abstract.para: The major research questions are: (1) In relation to a systematic survey conducted in the 1970s, determine whether the same suite of species can be found, and (2) whether trends in elemental deposition patterns are evident both spatially and, to a limited degree, temporally (mid-1970s compared to 1998) based on an analysis of populations.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Maricopa County is located in Central Arizona, USA.

description.para: This research study has been completed.

section.title: Digestion Procedure and Analytical Methods
section.para: In the laboratory, lichen thalli of approximately 6-8 cm in diameter were selected, removed from the rock substrate with plastic forceps and cleaned thoroughly using nano-pure water. This cleaning step removed most of the surficial particulates, though some remaining particles had to be removed by sonication. The cleaned thalli were stored in nitric acid-washed glass beakers until air-dry. To minimize intrathalline and interthalline elemental variation at each sampling, the lichen material was then frozen with liquid nitrogen, crushed in a clean mortar and pestel, and homogenized. Initial experiments tested elemental recoveries of different digestion procedures. For the lichen samples, conventional wet digestion procedures, using concentrated nitric acid and hydrochloric acid digestion, was selected as the best procedure. The accuracy of the digestion procedure was checked against the lichen standard L0002 of Dr. Jean Carignan, France.

All lab ware was cleaned for 48 h in a 10% nitric acid bath, and then rinsed three times in nanopure water to minimize metal contamination. Lichen material from each location was subdivided into three replicates of 0.1 g each (oven dry weight), and transferred into 15 ml screw-top teflon vials with 5 ml of 14 M nitric acid (Ultrex). First, the vials closed loosely and fluxed at 80°C on a hot plate in a fume hood. After fuming, the vials were closed tightly, and the samples digested overnight at 160°C. These samples were evaporated at 160°C to near dryness and redissolved in 1 ml of 12 M HCl (Ultrex) and 1 ml of 14 M HNO3 (Ultrex). These samples were again refluxed at 80°C, dried at 160°C to near dryness, and resuspended in a final mixture of 1 ml of 6 M HCl (Ultrex) and 2 ml of 7 M HNO3 (Ultrex). This suspension containing the free metals was refluxed at 80°C for approximately 30 min and then gravimetrically brought to a volume of 20 ml.

Before quantitative analysis, samples were spiked with 1 ml of an indium internal calibration standard. Elemental concentrations for a suite of 28 trace metals (antimony [Sb], cadmium [Cd], cerium [Ce], chromium [Cr], cobalt [Co], copper [Cu], dysprosium [Dy], europium [Eu], gadolinium [Gd], gold [Au], holmium [Ho], lead [Pb], lutetium [Lu], neodymium [Nd], nickel [Ni], palladium [Pd], platinum [Pt], praseodymium [Pr], samarium [Sm], scandium [Sc], silver [Ag], terbium [Tb], thulium [Tm], tin [Sn], uranium [U], ytterbium [Yb], yttrium [Y], and zinc [Zn]) in each sample was quantified using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The ICP-MS was run in the peak jump mode counting at key masses per element and scanning only for a select number of isotopes. This helped to reduce potential interferences and also reduced analysis time. Blanks were run along the entire sample preparation procedure and were uniformly much lower than the replicates from the same location.

description.para: the raster was obtained by interpolating among the 28 locations using Inverse Distance Weighted (IDW). with the following settings: spatial resolution of 300 map units, nearest neighbor analysis, 20 points, power of 5, and no barriers.
